Eisenhower Reveals

Budget Near Completion
By MICHAEL HILL
President Eisenhower met
Yesterday with the Budget
Committee of the Board of
Trustees as the figures for the
1971-72 budget were finalized.
The budget will be
presented to the full board in
a meeting next Monday, and
Eisenhower refused
to
discuss specific figures
before that session.
"The budget is the
responsibility of the Board,
and to have any preliminary
Publicity would tend to undermine their authority," the
Interim head stated.
Substantial Cuts
The president did say that
he had been able to make
substantial budget cuts
during his month in office,
stating, "We are not making
cuts which impinge upon the
central purpose of the
University, education and
research."
"We are cutting things that
You can do without that would
have been desirable," the
president said, revealing that
the latest figures show that
the school will suffer a $4.7
million dollar cash deficit for
the current fiscal year.
This is down from a
budgeted figure of $4.9
million, but up from previous

predictions of $4.3.
Eisenhower said that next
year's deficit would be "a
great deal less," adding that
the most serious problem
would continue to be the Arts
and Sciences division.
Looking back on the first
month of his return to the
president's
chair,
Eisenhower complained that
he has spent 75 percent of his
twelve hours a day, seven
days a week" working on the
financial problem.
"We have to notify the
Deans and the departments
of their budgets for next year
by June 15. After that, I can
turn to other matters," the
president stated, indicating
that these other matters
might include an examination
of the present method of
student input into the
governance system.

larger amount of time in fund

Housing Fees Up;
Services Cut Back
By IVAN JUAN ANTONIO JOSE
RODRIGUEZ—MENENDEZ
In accordance with recommendations made by
the Housing Committee.
Wolman Hall will become an
undergraduate
residential
hall beginning next year.
Several Housing Committee proposals formulated
over the last two semesters,
were recently ratified by
George S. Benton, Dean of
Arts and Sciences, and other
Arts and Sciences administrators. This was made
public in the Homewood information bulletin of May 5th.
Another of the ratified
proposals calls for an increase in rates and a
decrease in services in the
Alumni dorms. Dormitory
officials are highly critical of
the action.
"We felt that the recommendations we made would
significantly ease the housing
problem here," commented
one member of the Housing
Committee.
He added, "It would be
pretty difficult at this point
to predict whether these
changes are indicative of any
sort of trend. I suppose we'll
just have to wait and see what
happens next year." .
Wolman hall
Currently, Wolman Hall is
occupied
by
graduate
students. Those now living
there will be granted the
option of remaining next year
or will be given first priority

consideration in transferring
to any of the other three
university-owned apartment
buildings, the Bradford.
McCoy. and Homewood
apartments.
Freshmen women who can
not be placed in the dorms
will be given first priority for
new assignments in Wolman.
Second in line for apartment
space will be handicapped
students and upperclass
women followed by foreign
and minority students. Any
remaining apartments will be
leased to upperclassmen.
New policies affecting the
dormitories have met severe
criticism. The price of room
and board will be increased to
$1290 for next year and dorm
services will be cut back
drastically. Linen service will
be discontinued and maid
service may be eliminated as
well.
Mrs. Lois Van Norman,

Manager,
remarked, "I'm not at all
sure that the proposed moves

service will upset upperclassmen and I think it
will eventually cause this
place to deteriorate to a
tenement."

decreasing services; they're
trying to rip-off money from

BRP Readies A Report
By BRUCE STEVENSON
The Blue Ribbon Panel on
Undergraduate Education is
finally making headway in its
investigations and will issue
an interim report during the
final week of May.
The interim report will be
made up of four subcommittee reports, the first
of which was submitted at
Monday's meeting.
The
majority of the report
recommended
increased
course offerings and teaching
loads, and better communications between the
student and departments.
A few members of the
committee continue to doubt
the effectiveness of the panel.
Jim Philps charged last week
that the committee is just too
small to deal with the number
of problems that are being
considered.
Standards
The subcommittee's first
report recommended a
standard of four onesemester courses a year per
professor, at least three to be
open to undergraduates;
professors would teach at
least one independent study
course for an undergraduate
per semester.
Another section of May's
preliminary report may be
devoted to a brief statement

concerning the adverse
conditions under which the
panel has been operating. Dr.
Richard Kokes, chemistry,
will attempt to construct this
statement. Panel members
indicated that a major problem has been the lack of
cooperation from the administration concerning the
desired direction of the
BRP's work.
Kokes said, "It's hard to
find direction when we keep
getting knocked over the head
by the administration,
Eisenhower, and the Student
Council. They're all trying to
give us a different path to
follow!"
On Advising
In addition to the four
subcommittee reports, Dr.
William Hartman, a panel
member, would like to see a
section devoted to advising
policies at Hopkins. "It may
not be given a thorough investigation, but if I have
anything to do with it, advising will be included in this
report," Hartman said.
The remainder of the
subcommittee report centered on the course offerings
and professors' teaching
requirements.
The report
offered four possible ways to
improve teaching quality at
Hopkins.

They were: 1) to- create
symbolic or monetary prizes
for superior teaching; 2) to
give the Academic Council
power to evaluate teaching
quality and to consider the
promotion of professors; 3) to
require departments to increase their teaching loads;
and 4) to distribute funds to
reward certain departments
and faculty members for new
course offerings.

Private Gifts Drop;
Economy A Factor
By RICHARD BLAND

Private gifts to the division
of Arts and Sciences are down
drastically to just under 40%
of the correspondding totals
for last year.
Officers of the Development Office cite national
economic troubles, the
current absence of a permanent president, and substantial budget cuts as
largely responsible for the
losses.
Development Office figures
show that durng the first nine
months of fiscal 1971, Arts
and Sciences received only
$637,361, as compared with
$1,505,470 for the same period
a year ago.
The overall nine-month
figures for the University
show a decrease of more than
two million dollars from last
year to $7,047,546.
The Economy
Ellery Woodworth, Vice
President for Development,
blamed the country's lackluster economy for the
decrease in gifts. "We've had
trouble matching up donor
interests with our particular
needs," he said.
"Fund-raising isn't perfect," he added. "Active and
aggressive maintenance of
the right kinds of contacts
takes time and patience."
Edgar Feingold, Director
of Public Relations for the
Johns Hopkins Fund, stated
that the University plans to
launch a major fund-raising
campaign. He added, however, that such a campaign
would have to wait the appointment of a permanent

University president who
would have the opportunity
to examine the requirements
'carefully.
Woodworth indicated that
the Central Development
Office's situation would be
complicated by a budget cut
until the major fund drive
gets under way. The cut
would involve the release of
approximely 15 members of
the professional and clerical
staff.
Two divisions of the
University besides Arts and
Sciences show losses over last
year's totals, while the
remaining
three
have
registered gains.
Gifts to the School of
Hygiene have catapulted
down from last year's
$1,462,473 to $728,146. The
School of Medicine is down
from $4,994,015 to $3,026,696.
The genetal University
funds are up to $937,156 from
$526,759 in private gifts. The
Hospital is up from $395,047
to $490,318. Gifts to SAIS, the
School of Advanced International Studies, have
soared from last year's
contributions of $494,567 to a
current $1,227,869.
Sources of private gifts
include trustees and alumni,
other individuals, corporations, foundations and health
organizations.

$3,010,158, trustees and

individuals $744,658, Health

fessionalism required at
